questions.question: What does CPU stand for?
questions.explanation: CPU: main processor chip. Function: executes instructions. Speed: measured GHz. Cores: multiple processing units. Name: often referred to as processor. Importance: determines computer capability.

questions.question: What does RAM stand for?
questions.explanation: RAM: temporary fast storage. Speed: much faster than storage. Capacity: 8GB-64GB typical. Volatility: lost when powered off. Types: DDR4, DDR5. Purpose: active program storage.

questions.question: What does SSD stand for?
questions.explanation: SSD: storage without moving parts. Speed: faster than HDD. Reliability: no mechanical failure. Types: SATA, NVMe. Capacity: 256GB-4TB typical. Durability: proven reliable.

questions.question: What does HDD stand for?
questions.explanation: HDD: traditional rotating storage. Speed: slower than SSD. Capacity: large, cost-effective. Lifespan: 3-5 years typical. Failure: mechanical issues possible. Cost: cheaper than SSD.

questions.question: What does USB stand for?
questions.explanation: USB: standard connection interface. Purpose: data transfer, power delivery. Versions: USB 2.0, 3.0, 3.1, Type-C. Speed: increases per generation. Compatibility: widely supported.

questions.question: What does GPU stand for?
questions.explanation: GPU: specialized graphics processor. Function: rendering images. Speed: very high parallel processing. Uses: gaming, AI, graphics. Types: integrated, dedicated. Importance: gamers priority.

questions.question: What does BIOS stand for?
questions.explanation: BIOS: initial boot firmware. Function: hardware detection, boot process. Replacement: UEFI modernized version. Access: delete/F2 key often. Purpose: load operating system. Settings: hardware configuration.

questions.question: What does OS stand for?
questions.explanation: OS: manages computer resources. Examples: Windows, macOS, Linux. Function: runs programs, manages files. Updates: security patches regularly. Importance: fundamental software layer.

questions.question: What does API stand for?
questions.explanation: API: allows programs communication. Purpose: functionality access. Examples: weather API, payment APIs. Documentation: explains usage. Standardization: makes development easier.

questions.question: What does GUI stand for?
questions.explanation: GUI: visual computer interaction. Elements: windows, buttons, menus. Advantage: user-friendly compared to CLI. Development: easier learning curve. Standards: consistent across applications.
